title: Big-O Runtime of Loops — Nested, Logarithmic, and Tricky Increment Patterns | Neetechs Algorithms Tutorial

sections.title: Introduction (Wide Shot)
sections.content: Welcome back to Neetechs Tutorials. I'm your host, Sayed Jihad Al Sayed. Today we’re breaking down one of the hardest  topics: analyzing runtime of loops. If you can master loop analysis, you unlock Big-O for the rest of your degree. Your teacher LOVES these questions, so let’s crush them.

sections.title: What Is Runtime Analysis? (Wide Shot)
sections.content: Runtime analysis asks one question: how many times does the loop body execute as the input size n grows? We don’t care about seconds or milliseconds — we care about how the number of iterations scales with n. The key skill is reading loop boundaries and increments.

sections.title: Simple Loop Example (Close Shot + Screen Recording)
sections.content: Let’s start with a simple loop. This runs n times, so its runtime is O(n).

sections.title: Nested Loop Example (Wide Shot)
sections.content: Nested loops multiply. If the outer loop runs n times and the inner loop runs n times, the total work is n * n = n².

sections.title: Nested Loops With Different Bounds (Close Shot)
sections.content: If loops depend on different variables, we add them. Example:

sections.title: Triangular Loop Pattern (Close Shot)
sections.content: This is extremely common. The inner loop shrinks each time.

sections.title: Logarithmic Loop: i *= 2 (Wide Shot)
sections.content: Any loop that multiplies i instead of adding grows logarithmically.

sections.title: Logarithmic Loop: Division (Close Shot)
sections.content: Dividing has the same effect as multiplying.

sections.title: O(n log n) Loop Pattern (Wide Shot)
sections.content: A very common pattern: an O(n) loop with an O(log n) loop inside it.

sections.title: Tricky Loop: i += 3 (Close Shot)
sections.content: Constant step loops ignore the constant. They are still O(n).

sections.title: Dependent Loops Example (Wide Shot)
sections.content: These loops can appear confusing, but total work is what matters.

sections.title: While Loops With Halving (Close Shot)
sections.content: Any loop that halves the problem repeatedly is logarithmic. This is the same behavior Binary Search uses.

sections.title: Summation Intuition (Close Shot)
sections.content:
You do NOT need formal summation proofs in . You only need intuition:
- Filling a square grid → O(n^2)
- Filling a cube grid → O(n^3)
- Halving steps → O(log n)
- Nested loops inside halving → O(n log n)

sections.title: Common Exam Questions (Close Shot)
sections.content:
Your teacher usually asks:
- Identify O(n), O(n²), O(log n) patterns
- Nested loops complexity
- Logarithmic increments
- Dependent loops with i*j or i^2 bounds
- Combining independent loops
These are easy points if you know the patterns.

sections.title: Runtime Summary Table (Close Shot)
sections.content: Here’s your master cheat sheet:
sections.code:
| Pattern                      | Runtime     |
|------------------------------|-------------|
| Simple loop                  | O(n)        |
| Nested loops (n×n)           | O(n^2)      |
| Triple loop (n×n×n)          | O(n^3)      |
| Halving loop                 | O(log n)    |
| Nested + halving             | O(n log n)  |
| Loop with constant step      | O(n)        |
| Shrinking inner loop (triangular) | O(n^2) |

sections.title: Common Student Mistakes (Wide Shot)
sections.content: Most students overthink loop analysis. Don’t. The patterns repeat: if the loop shrinks by half, it’s log n. If loops multiply, it’s n² or more. If loops add, it’s n + m. If inner loop depends on i, look for triangular patterns or polynomial growth.

sections.title: Visual Recap (Wide Shot)
sections.content: Runtime analysis is pattern recognition. Simple loops are linear, nested loops multiply, halving loops are logarithmic, combinations give n log n. Once you see the structure, Big-O becomes easy.
